nodes.bodyText: I should add a try catch or maybe a default case that uses the old strings based approach.

I don't quite understand what you're checking here. It looks as if it's testing that the new byte representations have no overlaps with "legacy" txn statuses. Why do we need to run that test as part of this code? Surely you can make sure of that once (the status enums are constants, after all)?
I moved it into a test instead. It checks that the first byte in the old statuses isn't the same as the first byte in the new ones.
Can these be moved into the enum? And can they be made private?
Can we make this a private (final) field with a separate accessor method?
Do you want to put a further assertion here that after replaying the txn and getting everything in shape, the transaction file now uses the new format?
I found the TripleStoreRecoveryTest and based my test on that one, with the exception that I hardcoded the old "COMMITTING" string.
Does that work now that you've made it private? I would have expected you need to use getOnDisk() here instead.
Was surprised too. Seems that this is legal. No compile issues.
